comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Priceless! A million things worth commenting on: streetcars, newsboys, hats, clothing, urban fitness, advertisements, etc. And a well-turned calf in the bargain!

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
Another of the genre!  Previous "ample bottoms boarding trolleys" in the Commons...
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3681843789/]

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: The finish on the streetcar would have been gorgeous! Possibly dark (Brewster) green body, with lettering and wide striping in gold leaf. Fine striping in a contrasting color like apple green or crimson would have run parallel to the gold leaf striping. All the decorative elements protected with several coats of clear finishing varnish. Sweet!

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
The same bow tie advertisement near the front also appears in this photo from July 10th, 1913 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3738796499/in/set-72157603624867509/]

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The open-sided street cars were used only in summer. The benches on these cars were configured in transverse rows, unlike those of the winter cars, which lined the sides while facing a central aisle. Here there was no aisle. Instead, the passenger swung herself up from a running board, after making a quick check of the benches, to be sure of seating space on the one chosen. The conductor collected fares from the running board, while the car was in motion. (A doubly awkward task when rain was pouring down.)

comment.author: 35005631@N02
comment._content: Wonderful historical social document and great additions!
